questions.text: A patient presents to you with a deviation of the left eye. On doing PBCT you find differences in the neutralization of corneal reflex in different gazes. The amount of squint( esotropia) increases in upgaze & decreases in downgaze. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A Pattern esotropia A-V pattern squint is a type of incomitant squint. An A-pattern esotropia is an inward deviation of the visual axes in which there is more inward deviation of the eyes in midline upgaze than in midline downgaze . An A-pattern exotropia is an outward deviation of the visual axes in which there is more divergence of the eyes in midline downgaze than in midline upgaze.

Highyeild:

‘A’ and ‘V’ phenomena A tendency for the eyes to diverge on elevation is physiological. Any squint can show a variation in deviation in upward and downward gaze and, depending on the nature of the squint, an ‘ A’ or ‘V’ pattern can be recognized. For example, a ‘V’ pattern is seen in a convergent squint which increases on a downward gaze but in a divergent squint, a ‘V’ pattern is seen when the deviation is maximum in an upward gaze and less in a downward gaze. The ‘A’ and ‘V’ phenomena should be assessed by the cover test in 25°upward and downward gaze. In general, it is found that the oblique muscles are of more importance in the production of the ‘A’ and ‘V ’ phenomena than the vertical recti. Usually, overaction of the inferior oblique or weakness of the superior oblique leads to a ‘V’ pattern and overaction of the superior oblique weakness of the inferior oblique to an ‘A’ pattern. Weakening and strengthening of the oblique muscles, therefore, are well-recognized methods of influencing the ‘A’ and ‘V’ phenomena.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . An A-pattern exotropia is an outward deviation of the visual axes in which there is more divergence of the eyes in the midline downgaze than in the midline upgaze. A pattern deviation is considered clinically significant when the difference between upgaze & downgaze is at least 10PD. Options: C and D .For V pattern deviation it's 15PD. a ‘V’ pattern is seen in a convergent squint which increases on a downward gaze but in a divergent squint, a ‘V’ pattern is seen when the deviation is maximum in an upward gaze and less in a downward gaze.

questions.text: Brown’s syndrome is characterized by the involvement of which muscle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior oblique Brown's syndrome is characterized by a taut superior oblique leading to mechanical restriction of elevation in adduction. It can be congenital or acquired due to causes like trauma to the trochlear region, tenosynovitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. It is characterized by an absent elevation in adduction & being present in abduction. Forced Duction Test is positive in an attempt to elevate the adducted eye.

Highyeild:

In Brown syndrome, there is an inability to elevate the adducted eye above the mid-horizontal plane . Less restriction of elevation is apparent in the midline and an even smaller elevation deficiency is detectable in abduction. A slight down shoot of the adducting involved eye is often present. A widening of the palpebral fissure on adduction is associated with this restriction of elevation . Ten per cent of cases are bilateral. Brown syndrome is caused by a tight or short, relatively inelastic, superior oblique muscle and/or tendon and is present in varying degrees. The superior oblique tendon weakening procedure is carried out in Brown syndrome, secondary to a taut superior oblique tendon.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Superior rectus: not involved in Brown's syndromeOption: C. Inferior rectus: not involved in Brown's syndromeOption: D. Inferior oblique: not involved in Brown's syndrome

questions.text: The basis of secondary deviation being much greater than the primary deviation in paralytic squint is?

options.label: A
options.text: Hering’s law of equal innervations of yoke muscles

questions.correct_answer: A. Hering’s law of equal innervations of yoke muscles
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hering’s law of equal innervations of yoke muscles The primary deviation is the deviation of the affected eye when the unaffected eye is used for fixation. It is away from the action of paralysed muscle. The secondary deviation is the deviation of the unaffected eye seen under cover when the patient is made to fix the affected eye. The secondary deviation is much more than the primary deviation in paralytic squint based on Hering's law of equal innervations of yoke muscles.

Highyeild:

Neurological control of ocular movements Laws governing the neural control of ocular movements Laws governing the neural control of ocular movements are as follows: The Hering law of equal innervation applies to both eyes. Equal and simultaneous innervation flows from the brain to a pair of synergistic (yoke) muscles which contract simultaneously inconjugate binocular movements . For example, in leftoversion, the lateral rectus of the left eye and medial rectus of the right eye receives an equal and simultaneous flow of innervation; during convergence, both medial recti; and so on. In the case of a paretic squint, the amount of innervation to both eyes is always determined by the fixating eye so that the angle of deviation will vary according to which eye is used for fixation Sherrington law of reciprocal innervation : During the initiation of an eye movement, increased innervation to an extraocular muscle is accompanied by simultaneous inhibition (a reciprocal decrease innervation) of the direct antagonist of the contracting muscle of the same eye. If the left medial rectus muscle receives innervation flow to initiate adduction of the left eye, there is simultaneous decrease and inhibitory flow to the left lateral rectus muscle to make it relax and enable the eyeball to move medially.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Sherrington’s law of reciprocal innervations Sherrington (1906) described reciprocal innervation as the process that controls agonist and antagonist muscle actions. One muscle group (agonists) must relax to allow another group (antagonists) to contract. This is called reciprocal inhibition . Option: C. Donder’s law The rule, known as Donders' law, states that for each gaze direction, there exists a single corresponding eye orientation irrespective of how the eye was brought to this position Option: D. Listing’s law Listing's law states that, when the head is fixed, there is an eye position called primary position, such that the eye assumes only those orientations that can be reached from the primary position by a single rotation about an axis in a plane called Listing's plane .

questions.text: A patient with right lateral palsy is being examined by you. On asking to locate the objects to his right he points them further than they are actually located. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Past pointing This is a false projection as experienced by palsies of recent onset. Patients are unable to locate the object in space, they locate it further away in the same direction. It occurs due to increased innervational impulse conveyed to the paralysed muscle during movement in the direction of action of paralysed muscle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Diplopia - Diplopia is the medical term for double vision or seeing double. Diplopia is defined as seeing two images of a single object when you're looking at it. Double vision is usually a temporary issue, but it can also be a sign of more serious health conditions. Option: C. Confusion - Mental confusion can have causes that aren't due to underlying disease. Examples include stress, sleep deprivation, information overload, intoxication or exposure to new situations. Option: D. Amblyopia - Lazy eye (amblyopia) is reduced vision in one eye caused by abnormal visual development early in life. The weaker — or lazy — eye often wanders inward or outward. Amblyopia generally develops from birth up to age 7 years. It is the leading cause of decreased vision among children.

Extraedge:

TYPES OF AMBLYOPIA Type Description Strabismic Misalignment of eyes (strabismus) results in visual cortex suppression of the visual input of the deviating eye Anisometropic Difference of visual acuity (refractive error) between eyes leads to visual blurring of one eye and visual cortex suppression of the visual input of the blurred eye Combined strabismic and anisometropic Eye misalignment and refractive error leads to visual cortex suppression of the chronically blurred image Ametropic Bilateral, symmetric high refractive error resulting in blurred vision in both eyes and inadequate development of the visual cortex Deprivation Obstruction of the visual axis results in suppression of the visual cortex

questions.text: Characteristic associations of Duane’s Retraction Syndrome(DRS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Retraction of the globe on adduction

options.label: B
options.text: Narrowing of palpebral fissure on abduction

options.label: C
options.text: Marked limitation of movements on abduction

questions.correct_answer: A. Retraction of the globe on adduction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retraction of the globe on adduction DRS is a type of congenital cranial dysinnervation disorder(CCDD) characterised by the following features- Marked limitation of movements on adduction, 2. Retraction of the globe on adduction. Slight limitation of movements on abduction, 4. Narrowing of palpebral fissure on adduction & widening on abduction, 5. Upshot & down the shoot of the eye in adduction

Highyeild:

Congenital incomitant strabismus It is usually due to the infectivity of a muscle owing to its mal insertion , sometimes due to a defect or absence of the nervous motor mechanism (congenital double elevator palsy), sometimes due to fibrosis of the muscle (congenital fibrosis), sometimes due to abnormal synergistic innervation (Duane retraction syndrome) and occasionally due to the absence of the muscle itself. One of the common congenital defects is Duane retraction syndrome. It is due to fibrosis of the lateral rectus or an innervational anomaly with co-contraction of the lateral and medial recti . In the primary position, the eyes are straight or show some latent convergence, but there is a restriction or absence of abduction . On adduction, there is a retraction of the globe and narrowing of the palpebral fissure while on attempted abduction there is a slight protrusion of the eyeball with the widening of the palpebral fissure. The simple recession of the appropriate muscle or muscles rids the patient of the abnormal head position without risking induced vertical tropias.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Retraction of the globe on adduction Option: B. Narrowing of palpebral fissure on abduction Option: C. Marked limitation of movements on abduction

questions.text: A patient presents to you as a diagnosed case of R/E lateral rectus (LR) palsy from outside. You examine the patient to look for the amount of deviation. Which gaze do you expect to get the maximum deviation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In dextroversion LR palsy is the most commonly encountered paralytic squint . Paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint meaning the amount of deviation is different in different gazes. In a paralytic type of squint, the deviation is maximum in the direction of action of the paralyzed muscle. Since the action of the lateral rectus muscle is abduction so the deviation is maximum in lateral gaze. Type of Sixth Nerve Palsy

Highyeild:

Paralysis of the lateral rectus (sixth cranial nerve) There is an esotropia or convergent squint with a limitation of movement outwards , and the face is turned towards the paralysed side. Since the action of the lateral rectus muscle is abduction so the deviation is maximum in lateral gaze . The signs and symptoms of paralysis of any extraocular muscle are as follows: Squint Limitation of ocular movements Diplopia False orientation Abnormal position of the head Vertigo The sequence of secondary changes after muscle paralysis
